Chapter 2.45

Mid-January, 1438, Morning

You are in your solar at the Alcázar of Toledo, seated across from Don Álvaro de Luna. The conversation about Prince Henry's African expeditions has just concluded—the Senegal outpost operational, the Timbuktu expedition last heard from eight months ago, results not expected until 1439. Morning light streams through the narrow windows, catching the dust motes that drift lazily in the air. A brazier crackles softly in the corner, warding off January's chill.

The past week has been rich with discoveries. Two nights beneath the stars with Catalina and Fernando. The revelation that your brilliant daughter may never feel the transcendence she so desperately seeks—but that she has found a path forward nonetheless. The discovery that Fernando, your heir, cannot bring himself to swing a sword at another child—yet commands natural loyalty from the boys of the Plaza de Zocodover with nothing but kindness and curiosity. The naming of Nicolás, your second son, securing the succession at last.

Somewhere in Toledo, a messenger is riding toward the monastery of San Juan de los Reyes, bearing a summons for Brother Hernando—the young Franciscan friar Don Álvaro recommended as a spiritual guide for Catalina. A man, Álvaro said, who teaches novices and is known for his patience. A man who might be comfortable saying "I do not know."

Don Álvaro shuffles the papers on the table between you, setting aside his notes on the African ventures. He looks up.

"There are other matters requiring Your Majesty's attention," he says. "The new fiscal year has begun. Naples remains... restless. And there is the question of the meeting at Tenedos."

He waits.

Through the solar's windows, Toledo spreads beneath you in the pale winter light, smoke rising from a thousand chimneys, the Tagus glinting silver where it catches the sun.

Diego de Daza arrives first, as expected. The royal administrator has aged visibly in the years since you first elevated him—more grey in his beard, deeper lines around his eyes—but his ledgers remain immaculate and his mind sharp. He carries a leather satchel bulging with documents.

"Your Majesty called for me?"

When all are settled—Álvaro, Diego, Fernán, and yourself around the table—Diego spreads his documents with the precision of a man who has organized a kingdom's finances.

"If Your Majesty wishes to review the fleet..." He produces a summary sheet. "As of January 1438, the royal fleet stands at one hundred and six vessels. Slightly below Admiral Vilaragut's projection of one hundred and eight—we lost two naos to a storm off Sardinia last autumn, and one carrack is in extended refit at La Cartuja." He glances at the figures. "Twenty carracks, twenty-three naos, thirteen galleys, thirty-six fishing and utility vessels, fourteen patrol craft."

He produces a second sheet. "The Military Orders' fleet at Almería has exceeded projections. Twenty-nine vessels—the Masters have invested heavily from their own revenues. Santiago alone fields eleven war galleys now."

Captain Fernán leans forward. "And the Portuguese, Your Majesty? Since the union formalized..." He looks to Álvaro.

Álvaro picks up the thread. "King Duarte's fleet operates independently but coordinates with ours for Eastern operations. Prince Henry maintains his exploration vessels separately. For purposes of combined operations, Portugal contributes approximately forty vessels capable of Mediterranean service—though their strength lies more in Atlantic-capable carracks than galleys."

Diego tallies quickly. "Combined Castilian and Portuguese forces available for Eastern deployment: approximately one hundred seventy-five vessels. Add allied contributions—Aragon, Venice if they commit, the Hospitallers at Rhodes—and we approach two hundred fifty."

He sets down his quill and looks up.
